answer:
Common reactions to the Shingrix vaccine include headache as well as soreness, redness, and swelling where the vaccine was given. Other reactions which may occur include fever, muscle soreness, fatigue, shivering, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. These side effects are temporary and usually last 2-3 days. 
If you have concerns regarding a vaccine reaction, it is recommended that you contact the health care provider that gave you the vaccine. If you do not know who gave you the vaccine, you can contact your local health unit and speak with a public health nurse. It is important to always report serious or unexpected reactions to your health care provider. 
If you are concerned about your health, please speak with your health care provider. You can also contact HealthLink BC at 8-1-1.
Immunization Nurse
answer_formatted:
## Common reactions to the Shingrix vaccine include headache as well as soreness, redness, and swelling where the vaccine was given.

Other reactions which may occur include fever, muscle soreness, fatigue, shivering, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
These side effects are temporary and usually last 2-3 days.
If you have concerns regarding a vaccine reaction, it is recommended that you contact the health care provider that gave you the vaccine.
If you do not know who gave you the vaccine, you can contact your local health unit and speak with a public health nurse.

## It is important to always report serious or unexpected reactions to your health care provider.

If you are concerned about your health, please speak with your health care provider.
You can also contact HealthLink BC at 8-1-1.
Immunization Nurse
